author: Leicester Mercury
title: Brexit vote prompts mixed views from Leicester and Leicestershire business leaders | Leicester Mercury
text:
Comments (0) 
Members of the city and county's business community have been left shocked at Britain voting to leave the EU. 
Some warned the economy might slow down and said the Government had to act swiftly to calm the uncertain months ahead. 
However, others were more optimistic, saying Britain needed a new start and would be all the better for Thursday's In/Out referendum. 
He said: "In uncertain and worrying times we want the politicians to do their job, bring people together and stay calm. 
"I think people are thinking very hard about whether to make big decisions. 
"I'm not a doom-monger, and change brings opportunity, and opportunity brings potential growth and prosperity. 
"If we keep our heads and manage the situation, in the long term we might all benefit." 
Jane Cowley, a partner at law firm Howes Percival, in Braunstone , said: "Everybody I have spoken to is in a state of shock. 
"I think there are business owners who have delayed making decisions pending the vote and I think everyone is now going to re-evaluate." 
Pete Patel, managing director of Asian snack maker Cofresh, in Leicester, said: "Overall I'm very disappointed. I thought it was best for the country to stay in the EU. 
"I think we're going to see a turbulent few weeks until the market calms down. 
"But it is difficult to comment on what I think will happen in terms of currency and tariffs, as it is too early to say." 
Mike Kirsopp, chief executive at Cambridge and Counties business bank, based in New Walk, Leicester, was more optimistic. 
He said: "I think it was less a surprise than maybe others in my industry thought because the big sentiments for leave were in the Midlands and North where our business is focused. 
"We prepared for both eventualities and always thought it would be close, but we are UK focused so do not have importers and exporters in volumes. 
"We are planning for business as usual. 
"It always feels very raw in the first wave, but we've got months and years to sort this out." 
He said: "It's going to be very good for the country to get its independence back. Europe does not particularly like us. 
"I think we contribute more to the EU than we get back. 
"I would say, for instance, because we are not in the monetary system we won't really lose much trade. 
"I voted for Cameron's Government. His idea was to be in Europe, and he knew how to steer the country then, but he is not the right persons to make the right decisions now we are leaving. I want Boris to take over. I trust him." 
Sam Suffolk, operations director at metal working business CNC Direct Engineering in Countesthorpe, supplies Caterpillar among others. 
He said: "We are a businesses who exports some of our products to Europe. The pound has always been a high value. 
"Now that it is devaluing it is going to make anyone who exports competitive in the EU. 
"While the dust settles, we have got products people want and they are not going to stop wanting products from the UK."
